Overlap and Set-Based Metrics (Qualitative Focus)

Source: R/bdiv_set_based.r
bdiv_set_based.Rd

This family of metrics originates from the simple and intuitive idea of comparing two communities as if they were sets of species. The core calculation involves counting the number of species that are unique to each community versus those that are shared. By their nature, these metrics are primarily qualitative, focusing on membership rather than abundance, though quantitative extensions (Soergel and Motyka) are also included here.

Usage

hamming(counts, pairs = NULL, cpus = n_cpus())

jaccard(counts, pairs = NULL, cpus = n_cpus())

motyka(counts, pairs = NULL, cpus = n_cpus())

ochiai(counts, pairs = NULL, cpus = n_cpus())

soergel(counts, pairs = NULL, cpus = n_cpus())

sorensen(counts, pairs = NULL, cpus = n_cpus())

Arguments

counts

A numeric matrix of count data where each column is a sample, and each row is a feature. Any object coercible with as.matrix() can be given here, as well as phyloseq, rbiom, SummarizedExperiment, and TreeSummarizedExperiment objects.

pairs

Which combinations of samples should distances be calculated for? The default value (NULL) calculates all-vs-all. Provide a numeric or logical vector specifying positions in the distance matrix to calculate. See examples.

cpus

How many parallel processing threads should be used. The default, n_cpus(), will use all logical CPU cores.

Value

A dist object.

Details

Foundational Metrics: Jaccard and Dice-Sorensen

The Jaccard distance is perhaps the most fundamental set-based dissimilarity measure. It is derived from a measure of overlap, calculated as the size of the intersection of two sets divided by the size of their union. The Jaccard distance is then calculated as one minus this value. It is highly sensitive to the presence of rare species and effectively captures species turnover.

The Dice-Sorensen dissimilarity is closely related to Jaccard but gives double weight to the shared species. Its formula for overlap is twice the intersection divided by the sum of the number of species in each community. This subtle change makes it less sensitive to differences in overall species richness between the two samples compared to Jaccard. Like Jaccard, its dissimilarity is calculated as one minus this value.

The Otsuka-Ochiai dissimilarity is another related measure, derived from a value defined as the intersection divided by the geometric mean of the number of species in each community. It is the binary equivalent of the cosine dissimilarity and shares similar properties to the Jaccard and Dice-Sorensen dissimilarities.

Hamming Distance

The Hamming distance is a straightforward metric that counts the number of positions at which two vectors of equal length are different. When applied to presence/absence data, it simply counts the number of species that are present in one community but absent in the other, and vice versa. It is a direct measure of mismatches and is particularly useful in genetics and bioinformatics for comparing sequences.

Quantitative Extensions: Soergel and Motyka

While the above metrics are inherently binary, several have quantitative analogues that incorporate abundance data. The quantitative or weighted version of the Jaccard dissimilarity is derived from a measure calculated by summing the minimum abundance for each shared species and dividing by the sum of the maximum abundance. The Soergel distance is the corresponding dissimilarity measure (one minus the overlap value). Similarly, the Motyka dissimilarity is a quantitative version of the Dice-Sorensen dissimilarity. These quantitative extensions bridge the gap between set-based logic and abundance-based analysis, effectively calculating the proportion of shared abundance between two communities.

Calculation

Given:

\(x\):

Feature counts for the first sample.

\(y\):

Feature counts for the second sample.

\(n\):

Total # of features present in either samples.

\(A\):

Total # of features in the first sample.

\(B\):

Total # of features in the second sample.

\(J\):

Total # of features common to both samples.

Dice-Sorensen sorensen()

$$D = \displaystyle \frac{2J}{A + B}$$

Hamming hamming()

$$D = \displaystyle (A + B) - 2J$$

Jaccard jaccard()

$$D = \displaystyle 1 - \frac{J}{A + B - J}$$

Motyka motyka()

$$D = \displaystyle \frac{\sum_{i=1}^{n} \max(x_i, y_i)}{\sum_{i=1}^{n} (x_i + y_i)}$$

Otsuka-Ochiai ochiai()

$$D = \displaystyle 1 - \frac{J}{\sqrt{AB}}$$

Soergel soergel()

$$D = \displaystyle \frac{\sum_{i} |x_i - y_i|}{\sum_{i} max(x_i, y_i)}$$

  x <- c(4, 0, 3, 2, 6)
  y <- c(0, 8, 0, 0, 5)

  Dice-Sorensen
  2 * sum(x & y) / sum(x>0, y>0)
  #> [1] 0.3333333

  # Hamming
  sum(xor(x == 0, y == 0))
  #> [1] 4

  Jaccard
  1 - sum(x & y) / sum(x | y)
  #> [1] 0.8

  # Motyka
  sum(pmax(x, y)) / sum(x, y)
  #> [1] 0.8214286

  # Otsuka-Ochiai
  1 - sum(x & y) / sqrt(sum(x>0) * sum(y>0))
  #> [1] 0.6464466

  # Soergel
  sum(abs(x - y)) / sum(pmax(x, y))
  #> [1] 0.7826087

References

Levy, A., Shalom, B. R., & Chalamish, M. (2024). A guide to similarity measures. arXiv. doi:10.48550/arXiv.2408.07706v1

Cha, S.-H. (2007). Comprehensive survey on distance/similarity measures between probability density functions. International Journal of Mathematical Models and Methods in Applied Sciences, 1(4), 300–307.

Jaccard P (1908). Nouvellesrecherches sur la distribution florale. Bulletin de la Societe Vaudoise des Sciences Naturelles, 44(163). doi:10.5169/seals-268384

Dice, Lee R. (1945). Measures of the Amount of Ecologic Association Between Species. Ecology. 26 (3): 297–302. doi:10.2307/1932409

Hamming, R. W. (1950). Error detecting and error correcting codes. The Bell System Technical Journal, 29(2), 147–160. doi:j.1538-7305.1950.tb00463.x

Ochiai, A. (1957). Zoogeographical studies on the soleoid fishes found in Japan and its neighbouring regions. Bulletin of the Japanese Society of Scientific Fisheries. 23(7-8): 458-466.

Sorensen, T. (1948). A method of establishing groups of equal amplitude in plant sociology based on similarity of species and its application to analyses of the vegetation on Danish commons. Kongelige Danske Videnskabernes Selskab. 5 (4): 1–34.

Examples

    # Example counts matrix
    ex_counts
#>                   Saliva Gums Nose Stool
#> Streptococcus        162  793   22     1
#> Bacteroides            2    4    2   611
#> Corynebacterium        0    0  498     1
#> Haemophilus          180   87    2     1
#> Propionibacterium      1    1  251     0
#> Staphylococcus         0    1  236     1
    
    hamming(ex_counts)
#> Error in validate_normalized(<environment>): could not find function "validate_normalized"
    
    jaccard(ex_counts)
#>          Saliva      Gums      Nose
#> Gums  0.2000000                    
#> Nose  0.3333333 0.1666667          
#> Stool 0.5000000 0.3333333 0.1666667
    
    motyka(ex_counts)
#>          Saliva      Gums      Nose
#> Gums  0.7132987                    
#> Nose  0.9856922 0.9860128          
#> Stool 0.9954754 0.9955523 0.9957588
    
    ochiai(ex_counts)
#>          Saliva      Gums      Nose
#> Gums  0.2236068                    
#> Nose  0.4082483 0.1825742          
#> Stool 0.6708204 0.4000000 0.1825742
    
    soergel(ex_counts)
#>          Saliva      Gums      Nose
#> Gums  0.5980627                    
#> Nose  0.9854845 0.9858144          
#> Stool 0.9954549 0.9955324 0.9957408
    
    sorensen(ex_counts)
#>           Saliva       Gums       Nose
#> Gums  0.11111111                      
#> Nose  0.20000000 0.09090909           
#> Stool 0.33333333 0.20000000 0.09090909
    
    # Only calculate distances for A vs all.
    jaccard(ex_counts, pairs = 1:3)
#>          Saliva      Gums      Nose
#> Gums  0.2000000                    
#> Nose  0.3333333        NA          
#> Stool 0.5000000        NA        NA
